Westhampton, July 22 1812
Honored & Respected Sir,
So high an opinion do I entertain of your humanity & politeness, as to persuade myself that you will excuse the liberty I am taking. 
I have been told that it was the intention of the Editors of the Panoplist to publish the journal which I kept in my late tour into Canada. It is with solicitude I request you, my Honoured Sir, if this be the case, to see that the part which respects the meeting & doings of the Protestant association be left out, for this  reason, the meeting was secret; as those who attended did not wish that the design of their coming together should be known to their Brethren, who profess to be Roman Catholics. 
It is my opinion, if it should be published, that it will do more hurt then good; as several copies of the Panoplist go regularly into Canada among the Romish Clergy, through the medium the Rev. Dr. Matignon, or some other person in Boston. 
I have several small religious tracts by me (of my own translation) in the Iroquois language; — and I wish to know by you Sir, whether any of them can be printed at the expence of "the Massachusetts Society for promoting christian knowledge."

Onieda March 28th, 1822.
Honoured & Respected Sir,

Yours of the 23d inst together with a copy of yours to Judge Dean was yesterday received. 
I am truly happy to find, that the letter written by you to Judge Dean has nothing in it which indicates, that money had been drawn as the Chiefs who wrote to you had understood. The letter lay some time in the hands of the Judge and a number of the opposition party saw it and put in circulation stories to the effect stated to you by the friendly Chiefs. 
I hope you will take no exception on account of their writing, as they did it in the simplicity of their hearts. You have long been acquainted with Indians and know something of their late contest, and the tenacity of there opinions. It has been the case for six months past that both parties have been writing to the President, Bishop and Governour — Wherefore, I hope you will not suppose it as a want of respect, especially as the party who lately wrote have stated to me, since the receipt of your Letter, the regret for the misunderstanding, and the highest respect, regard, and veneration for you. 
I am sorry to say that I fear too many people stand ready to write and serve the Indians and fear, when serving them that they often put words in their mouths — whether, they are friendly or not to the Indians, I cannot say. But permit me to remark that I am assured, and

Decision of the Commissioner in the Claim of E. Williams.
The fact of Mr. Williams having acted as the Agent or Delagate of the Oneida, and also that he was one of the principal agent in the nogotiation of the treaties of 1821 & 1822 are fully proved, as well by the admission of the chiefs as by the highest specis of evidence, viz: the treaties themselves and many written memoranda. The chiefs of the one party have, from the beginning opposed this claim, alledging several reason for that opposition, none of which, in the opinion of the commissioner as sufficient to destroy the claim of Mr. Williams: On the other hand, it appears that Mr. Williams has at different times, and when the Oneidas were poor, received from them many evidences of their kindness: It is also clearly proved that the claimant during the time he acted as the Agent of the Oneidas were the sole & regularly appointed deputy of the St. Regis tribe; and Mr. W. will be entitled to a claim for services

Washington April 27th 1858
Dear Sir,
My affairs are now in such a state, that my presence is now no longer necessary here and to avoid further expense, I am desirous to leave the city as soon as it may be. I am now in a debt 70 Dollars for my board and not a Dollar in hand to answer this demand. If you have recovered the sum mentioned in your Letter, may I ask you to send the same to Josiah F. Polk Esq. of this city. 
You did not mentioned the sum or the Bank where the check may be presented. You have I presumed, apprised? the Bank of its failure in reaching me — to prevent fraud!
The committee of the house have reported & printed wherein the Secretary of the treasurer is authorized to pay to the Rev. Eleazer Williams the sum of fourteen thousand dollars for services rendered &c. and that the name of said Eleazer Williams be placed upon the pension list as of the date May first 1856, and that he be entitled to receive, during his natural life, the yearly pension of two hundred & nineteen Dollars.
There is a movement & actually in operation in the Indian Committee, which greatly excites my feelings — & in which I am deeply interested — we are soon to be called upon to relinquishe our rights to the land in the Indian Territory, west of Missouri. A certain Mr. Thompson, who had 

Ayer N.A. ms. 1000a
Completed

a management of the Menominies Indians case, which is similar to the New York Indians now in the hands of the Committee, he was allowed forty thousand Dollars. Now my services in the later case is already acknowledged by the Committee and since this the case, it is the utmost importance that I should repair immediately to the New York Indians to receive the sum I am entitled to growing out of those services I rendered to them. I am actually in distress, (as now is the time) for want of money to accomplish this desirable object. Could you not obtain upon loan, one hundred & fifty Dollars for ninety days — and I will give a prime of fifty Dollars for the sum, and I will endeavour to be punctual for the return of the money at the time specified. I hope you will make a great effort in my behalf in this matter — I have every reason to believe that a large sum is now within my reach. — to lay a foundation for this, no time is to be lost. 
Let me hear from you as soon as convenient, and Mr. Polk will expect to hear from you. In great haste
I am dear Sir, yours
respectfully, Eleazer Williams

In the commencement of the year 1818, I could only say that my success had been thus far but partial; and from the course I had taken to disseminate the religious truths among the Oneidas, I was fully persuaded that it was the only made and I did not doubt it would ultimately be more successful, and therefor must be persevered in.
It was my hope among the other fruits of the spirit, which my friends the Episcopalians might derive from
Completed

my labours would be an increase of a mission spirit among them. For I had ever regarded, that all true and lasting missionary zeal as proceeding from that love to God and love to our neighbor which the Gospel enjoins, and which none but those who have the aid of the Spirit can possess. We can hardly expect to excite an intelligent & effectual interest in the Missions of the Church, unless we keep our people well informed concerning them. To this end, it is believed, that my Diocesan in his annual addresses to the convention, he mentioned of what we were doing at Oneida.
I had still met many discouraging events; but I have also had encouraging evidence of God's favor. This
Completed

or at least to hear from me that glorious Gospel spirit was at first proclaimed in the land of Palistine. This was most gloomy period of my mission. There were six nations of Indians, whose eternal salvation lay near my heart, & who had more than once invited me to visite them that they may hear the Gospel of Christ. & I saw then, that the church I had connected myself with, would not sustain me to the full extent of "my heart desires", so after many days of fasting, humiliation

prove in the end, a last to me, and this would have been the case had it not been for the friendly interference of Chancellor Kent, Lieut Governour Tayler of Albany, and the Hon's Nathan Williams & Morris S. Miller of Utica.
In consequence of this, my means to sustain myself since I entered into the Oneida Mission, had been very limited. My principal dependence to maintain myself, had been when $1.25, which the church in the state of New York allowed me.
My Indian Brethren, saw with their own eyes, I was contented with my humble living and had submitted to many inconveniences that I might be useful or to do them good.

When he first came to us, we hailed him as our friend, our brother, and our guide in spiritual things; and he shall remain in our hearts and minds as long as he shall teach us the ways of the great spirit above.

During the greater part of the winter I have endeavoured faithfully to instruct the Oneidas in the great truths of the Gospel, either in Lectures or in private instructions in their families. I trust my labours have been useful in some measure to them. I feel myself bound, by all the ties, that a complicated scene of unmerited goodness can lay one under, thankfully to adore and praise the god of all grace, for

And we hoped, there were goodly number, who, by the gracious influence of the spirit, were brought to rejoice in the truth, with Joy exceedingly great & full of glory. Well may we rejoice with them, that in the midst of deserved wrath, God remembered mercy for those who were ready to perish.

 We had a strong demonstration, in the midst of the tender solicitude of my Oneida friends, for true salvation of their souls, that although christians may pray for sinners, and the ministers of Christ entreat them, yet they will remain unmoved  The enquiry was often made, "why was this ?" So much so that Chiefs of the Six Nations concluded to have a general Council upon the subject. The many & various duties which I had been compelled to perform the year past, have, in a great measure impaired my health; so that about this time, I was scarcely able to go through the services on Sundays. In my communication to the Bishop on the 23d of Nov. I was under the necessity of informing him, that my health was in a feeble state - that I had a turn spitting blood & was grievously troubled with a pain in my breast - In congruence of which my friends were alarmed with my situation, and my attending Physicians

There is evidently a great & important revolution in the state of the Indian population already commenced, and now rapidly gaining forward, affecting immediately the tribes residing in the basons of the several states, and on the frontiers, and which, it is believed will ultimately & speedily be left by those not? the remotest distance. The evidence of this revolution exists in the peculiar interest which is felt and manifested for the general improvement & welfare of Indians, and in the peculiar corresponding feelings & movements among the Indians themselves. The Civil & religious commnties are remarkably awake on this subject,

Some of this is applicable to the case of the Six Nations in the State of New York. They have become sensible that there must be change not only in regard to their present residence, but their civil polity and the manner of obtaining their livehood. They see by the impudence of their former chief & by the intrigues of designing white men, their territories had become so limited & scarcity of timber, as to foresee that it can not be long before they must become in want, of this article, so necessary for their fires, buildings & fences.

The best and most successful means which could be employed by Government & religious societies to civilize the Indians, according to Dr. Maye opinion, was to learn them to cultivate the soil, as the whites do, - they will soon see the advantages of employing the plough, harrow & c. &c. and be indeed to imitate our example, and thus get on the road which leads to civilization before they are aware of it. I was kindly entertained by the President Monroe & the Secretary of War while in washington & by seasonal members of Congress by whose polite inviation, I was often a guest to their rich tables. Among others, I was noticed by the celebrated John Randolph of Virginia, in whose company I enjoyed much.  As I have met with the Rev. Dr. Morse, so we were together in the several interviews we had with the President & Secretary of War. It was arranged we were to take a exploring tour to the west the ensuing Spring & Summer. A certain number of the Six Nations St. Regis & Stockbridge Indians were to accompany me image of 2 circles with vertical lines through them, and letter P.  I here found that the State of New York was not only interested in the removal of our Indians but there were individuals as well as a company who had a claim to the Seneca

territory west, of a meridian line passing through or near the Seneca lake, & within the present limits of the State of New York. By an amicable adjustment between the two states in the year 1786, Massachusetts released to New York the sovereignty and governmental control over the territory, and New York surrendered to Massachusetts the right of soil, subject to the Indian title, and the right to extinguish the Indian title in her own way. Not many years after this period Massachusetts sold to private individuals her preemption right to the whole country, reserving that power of guardianship over the Indians which the old states have ever exercised within their limits, and which the United States have exercised without the limits of the states and within those limits, where the right of pre emption from the Indians belonged to this government. In this way & for

The interests of this company are direct & Palpable - The purchase from Massachusetts was made in 1796 or 1797, and so far as these lands are concerned, the purchase money paid to that state has been unproductive capital to the company, from that day to the present time. It is abundently shown too, that the present reservations are constantly being stripped of their timber which in their natural state constitute the chief value of two or three of them. The Sin forbidden is the worship of God by images, which is the second species of Idolatry, prohibited by the moral law.

 1. The reason of this prohibition is that God cannot be represented by any image, symbol or likeness of any thing wither among the works of nature or art.  He is a spiritual existance & all images are corporeal. They fall infinitely short of any Idea of him. They tend to divess the mind of those conceptions which we ought ever to form of God, as a being uncompounded, indivisible & omnipresent. They are therefore most unworthy of being held forth to the view of the mind as in any measure adequate to God & therefore are impious attempts to bring down the deity to a level with his creatures. God is a spirit infinite & eternal, and images & likenesses are material, corporeal & finite. This preference is every where, but an image is confined to one place, & therefore cannot represent him. No material image can represent a spiritual object, any more than the eye can discern sounds, or the ear colors. Our Lord hath taught us that as God is a spirit, he cannot be worshiped by any resemblances, but must be worshiped in spirit & in truth.
2. No doubt another reason prohibiting the  worship of God by images, is the danger of the mind, payg divine honors to the image, instead of him, whom the image is formed to represent or express.  1. The duty of children to their parents is to reverence, esteem & love their persons. They should cherish a cordial regard for them & express it by all suitable words & actions. Even tho' their parents may not be so worthy as others, yet are children bound to show them greater respect than others. This obligation is not destroyed, even tho' the parents one or both should be vicious & profane. They are the authors under God of their existance. Had it not been for them, they would not have been. Their training up in life has also been owing to the labor & care of their parents. Thus filial reverence & respect is due, even to vicious parents & Hill mac? to the worthy & virtuous, because from the latter children have received many more kindness & favors & their gratitude is in proportion to the favors recd from them.
 Children when young, before they arrive to years of discretion, are under the absolute rule & government of their parents, & bound to obey them in all things, not sinful or immoral; and after they have attained to years of discretion & in a capacity to provide for themselves in the World, they are bound to respect & reverence, their parents

Stated. ____ beg leave humbly to represent to your Honourable Body, that one G̲e̲o̲r̲g̲e̲ ̲J̲o̲h̲n̲s̲o̲n̲ has laid claims to a portion of the lands embraced in one of our treaties; that he claims them under an act of 1812, for granting these lands to the occupants, which have been improved since that time; but that the tract which he specifies has not been occupied or improved as the law directs, and consequently cannot come within the meaning of the act __ Wherefore we hope the subject may while under your inspection be thoroughly investigated.
